awd_titl_txt: CS4MS NIC: Growing Teacher Competency and Capacity
awd_abstract_narration:
Mississippi State University (MSU) proposes a research practitioner partnership structured as a network improvement community (NIC), called CS4MS NIC: Growing Teacher Competency and Capacity, which aims to build sustainable professional development (PD) to support the long-term success of secondary computer science education in Mississippi. The CS4MS NIC will identify, develop, and deliver additional PD for teachers who provide instruction in the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) course.

Mississippi has a goal of placing qualified computer science teachers in all K-12 schools by 2023-2024. Based on a needs assessment gathered from the 67 teachers currently teaching ECS as part of a Computer Science for Mississippi State pilot program, the project team has identified the need for additional computer science content training to augment the normal ECS PD. This training will provide teachers with an increased level of self-efficacy, enabling them to more confidently and proficiently teach the ECS course. In addition, the NIC will work with MSU's College of Education, Department of Computer Science, and the Mississippi Department of Education (MDE) to develop a licensure for a secondary education degree with a concentration in computer science. These educators will also work to establish an endorsement pathway for in-service teachers and an alternate route for industry professionals with a desire to teach at the secondary level.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 3-year project titled “CS4MS NIC: Growing Teacher Competency and Capacity” had and accomplished the following two goals:

  1. to identify, develop, and deliver additional computer science content training for high school teachers who are delivering the ECS curriculum as part of the ongoing CS State pilot and
  2. work with the MSU College of Education, the MSU Department of Computer Science, and the MDE to develop appropriate licensure and endorsement pathways for computer science teachers.

This project was created, and these goals established in response to feedback from teachers completing training during the pilot years (2016-2018) for the high school Exploring Computer Science (ECS) course. The ECS professional development program is structured to focus on preparing teachers to use computing concepts to develop problem-solving and critical thinking skills and does not provide significant depth of content instruction during the 9 days of training. This was problematic for Mississippi teachers who were primarily from content areas other than computer science. After the initial training, over half of the teachers surveyed indicated that they did not feel equipped with enough content knowledge to adequately teach the material.

In response to the lack of self-efficacy expressed by the teachers, extra training was developed that focused completely on the computer science content in each unit of ECS.  These trainings were offered in 3 sessions in both a face-to-face and online format.  Participants could choose the format they preferred and then were asked to provide feedback on the effectiveness of that format based on the material covered and their level of perceived growth in understanding. Below are results from post-surveys of the additional training sessions offered:

 Growth in teacher-expressed confidence:

            Unit 1 F2F increased by 12%, online increased by 12%

            Unit 2 F2F increased by 11%, online increased by 4%

            Unit 3 F2F increased by 14%, online increased by 3%

            Unit 4 F2F increased by 17%, online increased by 17%

            Unit 5 F2F increased by 31%, online increased by 22%

            Unit 6 F2F increased by 13%, online increased by 8%

In an end-of-year survey conducted by the external evaluator, 60% of respondents indicated that a combination of face-to-face training and online training is the most effective in increasing teacher confidence in computer science.  The remaining 40% preferred face-to-face.

This project has shown that much of the initial negative response to the ECS training was due to the pilot group being pioneers of the CS initiative in Mississippi – they had no content experience and were not implementing the practice of inquiry-based learning.  The end-of-project survey indicated that nearly all respondents, in hind-site, rated the ECS trainings received prior to teaching the class as at least somewhat valuable (90%), with half of all respondents rating them as extremely valuable.  Ninety percent of respondents likewise rated EXTRA ECS trainings as at least somewhat valuable ( half saw them as moderately valuable). This suggests that the EXTRA ECS trainings are good supplementary trainings to follow the initial ECS 9-day training program.

Reflections from the past 6 years have shown teachers new to computer science may react negatively to their first training experience. Used to being the "experts" in the classroom for the subject they teach, when they realize that after a week of training, they don't know everything about programming, they panic and often feel the training hasn't prepared them to teach the course.  This project has shown us that most teachers will respond differently to new CS instruction after they have had experience in the CS classroom.  They learn that not having all of the answers up front can actually make them a better teacher because they are more likely to model problem-solving and critical thinking skills for their students.

Over the course of this project, Mississippi has seen tremendous growth in both CS student enrollment and teachers trained.  There has been a 15.3% increase of students taking ECS courses between 2018 and 2022. This growth has been noted in gender and race participation as follows: Black student enrollment increased by 13.7%, LatinX by 102.5%, white by 4%, females by 13.4%, and males by 16%. The number of teachers actively teaching the ECS course has grown from 41 in 2017 to 110 in 2022 – a 168.3% increase.

Finally, this project facilitated the development of two add-on endorsements approved by the Mississippi Institutes of Higher Learning in the summer of 2019. The K-8 endorsement is 12 hours of course work over 4 courses (Digital Tools for 21st Century Teaching and Learning, Graphics and Web Design, Introduction to Computer Science Education, Advanced Information Processing). The 7-12 endorsement is 18 hours of course work over 6 courses (Computing and Cybersecurity Classroom Integration, Introduction to Computer Programming, Intermediate Computer Programming, Data Structures and Algorithms, Discrete Math, Introduction to Computer Science Education). These courses are available for both pre-service and in-service teachers.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Shelly R Hollis

work with the MSU College of Education, the MSU Department of Computer Science, and the MDE to develop appropriate licensure and endorsement pathways for computer science teachers.
